H0.text: The Earth turning on its axis best explains why the shape of the moon appears to change regularly during each month.

H1.text: The Moon turning on its axis explains why the shape of the moon appears to change regularly during each month.

H2.text: The Moon orbits around the Earth explains why the shape of the moon appears to change regularly during each month.

H3.text: Clouds covering the Moon explain why the shape of the moon appears to change regularly during each month.

A4.text: The appearance of the Moon (its phase) gradually changes over a lunar month as the relative orbital positions of the Moon around Earth, and Earth around the Sun, shift.

A5.text: Because the Moon is tidally locked to Earth, the cycle of phases takes one lunar month and moves across the same side of the Moon, which always faces Earth.
